title: How has technology impacted communication? - Quora

response.answer_text: The real question is how hasn't technology improved our communication. First and foremost “It Keeps Us Connected” We live in a very unique time in history that is marked by interconnectedness and information. You no longer have to wait to hear about your childhood best friend’s engagement thanks to social platforms like Facebook, and you can find out what is going on halfway across the globe in an instant with up-to-the-minute information from online news sources. Staying connected to the world around us can help with things like keeping the right perspective about what’s going on in your own life, and maintaining relationships with people you wouldn’t otherwise be able to. These advantages can be great for finding a job, reconnecting with old friends, and much more.

Much of the routine work in offices such as recording information, writing and sending Messages, calculating, gathering and analysing data has been taken over by machines. These functions can now be performed more quickly, more accurately and more efficiently and the time thus saved can be used for more challenging and simulating tasks. Every second the networks formed by telephones, telex printers, radio stations, and satellite links transmit millions of messages from one place to another. The main advantages of technology in communication processes are:- Manual writing or traditional type writing has been replaced by devices capable of producing neater and more legible document at a faster pace.Automation has reduced the incidence of error and the chances of fraud and has led to an increase in output.The boredom and fatigue caused by clercial work in handling and manipulating datahas been considerably diminished.In case of speechesand dialogues, the new technologies of speakers and microphones have added the reach to tremendous civilians.E-books,E-newspapers, E-mails etc. Has increased the reach pace of the information to audiance.Thus we see,technology is very helpful in communication.
